(Same as HIST 285 3)
(Complete topic:  China & the West through Travelers)
(This course will meet synchronously on Wed. 6:00 PM - 7:15 PM)
(This course covers a millennium of the history of interaction between China and the West by focusing on the adventures of travelers, missionaries, merchants, diplomats, and soldiers. The themes included in this course are states and empires, cross-cultural exchanges, identity formation, culture and religion, trade, plague, environment, and globalization.  We will examine how Chinese, Arabic, European, and Central Asian travelers witnessed the rise and fall of empires, trade routes, and extensive cultural interaction and confrontation. The timeline is loosely structured to be between 200 A.D. when the Han Empire and Roman Empire were connected through the silk road to the early twentieth century ending with Chinese laborers in the Western front and Jewish families in wartime China. This course is about stories of a shared human past. The reading of this course focuses primarily on travelers' writings while the lectures provide a broader historical context. No prior knowledge of Chinese language or history is required. This course enhances the students' understanding of the long history of global interaction and interconnection)
